conclusion: The problem involves calculating the magnitude of the Ampere force acting on a semi-circular wire frame in a uniform magnetic field.

The magnetic force on a wire is given by the equation F = (μ0 * I * L) / (2r), where μ0 is the permeability of free space, I is the current, L is the length of the wire, and r is the radius of the wire.

The wire frame is semi-circular with radius r, and points M and N are connected to a direct current constant voltage power supply. The plane of the wire frame is perpendicular to the magnetic field direction.
The length L of the semi-circular wire frame is calculated as L = 2r.
Substituting L = 2r into the equation for magnetic force, F = (μ0 * I * 2r) / (2r).
Simplifying the equation, F = μ0 * I.
Substituting the given values, F = 4π × 10^-7 Tm/A.
The magnitude of the Ampere force acting on the entire wire frame is 4π × 10^-7 Tm/A.
